column1: Facts
Climate change refers to a broad range of global phenomena created predominantly by burning fossil fuels.
The Earth's temperature has increased by at least 1.1 °C since the industrial revolution.
The Arctic ice has decreased by 40% since the 1980s.
Scientists predict that by the end of the century, our planet's average temperature could rise by up to 6.7°C.
Climate change is caused by greenhouse gases, with carbon dioxide being the most important.
The level of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere is at the highest measured levels in the last 800,000 years.
Global sea levels have risen by 20 centimeters since the industrial revolution.
Climate change is causing more frequent and severe weather events such as floods, heatwaves, droughts, and hurricanes.
Climate change is affecting animal and plant life, and some species are becoming threatened or extinct due to the changing climate.
The United Nations has introduced a global initiative, the Paris Agreement, to limit global warming to less than 2°C.
